bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, April 6, [1942]

div1.p: Kean commends Hench for his published article, expresses his pleasure in having read Roper's book on Reed, and sends news about Emilie Lawrence Reed's health. He also mentions the possibilities for publication of Truby's work and sends some newspaper clippings.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, April 6, [1942]
div1.opener:
2804 N H. n.w Wash. D.C.
April 6th
My dear Dr. Hench
div1.p:
It has been a month since your last
letter and I have had it in mind for a
week or more to write to you - not that I have
had anything very important to tell you but just
to keep in touch with your wonderful work and
not to miss anything. But I appreciate how
busy you are with all the things you put your hand
to and that you should not waste any time on
unproductive correspondence. You inclosed the
printed letter to members of the Amer. Rheumatism
Assn which served as an introduction to the
very valuable and informing article on diagnosis
and treatment of rheumatic diseases which is the
first paper in the Jan (number 60) issue of the
Army Medical Bulletin. When I read it I wished
that I could have done so fifty years ago.
I was pleased to Dr. Osgood's name with yours signed
to it. I have a great regard for him both for his admi-
rable work in the rescue and treatment of battle fractures
in the A.E.F. in France and for his skilful care and
advice in the treatment of my only son Robert
who was for some years an invalid from osteomyelitis
of the hip and ankle joints of the right leg. The hip
AC
K
2
joint was distroyed and ankylosed & he has still a
discharging sinus there after 29 years. But he has been
able to get his Ph.D. in chemistry and lead an active
useful life. I wonder when you will get time to study
the 40 photographs and that bibliofilm of 500 frames
which you received from the National Archives.

I recall having given one or two informal talks to the
Army Med. School on Sanitation in Cuba at the
request of the President of the School but nothing of impor-
tance. I have recently read most of Miss Laura
Wood's life of Walter Reed and am much pleased
with it. She has taken great pains to be accurate
and has made remarkably good use of the rather
scanty data about his boyhood experiences to make
it connect up into a biography. I put question marks
on the margin of her MSS where I doubted the accuracy
of her statements or was curious as to the source
of her information and I was much impressed
to see how widely she had ranged in her search
for facts and for the verification of her conclusions.
Her objective is much more modest and restricted
than your basic and conclusive researches; it is
to write a popular small biography for young people.
She has not written up the story of 1900-1901 yet.

We had a call about 2 weeks ago from Gen. & Mrs. W.L.
Reed and Mrs Blossom Reed and they told us that
J. R. K. to P.S.H.
3
within a week after your visit to their mother Mrs
Walter Reed, her mind began to fail so that now she
remembers only a few friends and hardly anything
of the usual incidents of life. They did not encou-
rage me to come to see her, as she would not recall
me and it would give her no pleasure, which
it would be painful to me. They planned to
take her up to Blue Ridge Summit to her Sum-
mer home this week. Blossom said she was so
thankful that you saw her before this rapid
deterioration began. She is 86 but it seems to
me that the progress of this senile dementia
has been unusually rapid, especially as she was
so well preserved in her physical and mental
faculties until quite recently.

I am glad to know that Truby sketch is in the
hands of Dr. F. F. Russell. You know we Army
Medical Men think there is no higher authority
in Preventive Medicine than F. F. Russell.
If the Surgeon General publishes Truby's sketch
as a Bulletin and sends a copy to each offi-
cer in the M. C. and the Med. Reserve I believe
it will give a much wider circulation, with this
great war on, than any plan of private
publication for sale, I suppose that this free
4
distribution would reach 25,000 medical men
and there should be an additional printing for
sale, at or near cost to libraries & individuals
which would make a much wider distribution than
in a war-time publication for sale. It is amazing
to what an extent war directs the attention of every
one including professional men away from their
usual channels of thought and mental activity.
Your publication which will be more important
than all these others put together should certainly
wait for the calm days of peace and I am glad
that you feel that way about it.

I am putting in a few old clippings enclosure 1 enclosure 2 enclosure 3 which may
interest you. Do not return them. I wrote the
one “ A Candidate for Honors”. It pleased Reed
but did not put a bee in his bonnet. General
O'Reilly was the man who got the appointment
and he took me into his office to be his executive
officer, altho. I think he was quite aware of my
Advocacy of Walter Reed. I have been look-
ing over a bunch of letters from Gorgas about his
troubles on the Canal Zone but I do not think they
contain anything of interest to you in your field
of study. I am feeling much better now and will
be glad to send you anything which may help you
that I can find.
